importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's update, indicating that the Supreme Court hearing on the Chicago National Guard deployment is currently active and expected to conclude soon.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision in the Chicago case within a few days, highlighting the immediacy and urgency of the legal and political debate.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump is urging the Supreme Court to allow the deployment of the National Guard to Chicago to suppress protests against ICE enforcement, citing a recent 9th Circuit ruling that supports presidential deference in such deployments.

The Trump administration argues that the deployment is necessary due to 'violent resistance' and draws a parallel to similar actions in Portland and Los Angeles, asserting that such decisions are entitled to great judicial deference.

The Department of Justice relies on the 1827 Supreme Court precedent, Martin v. Mott, to assert that the president alone has the authority to determine when national emergencies justify Guard deployment.

State and local officials, including Illinois officials and Judge April Perry, dispute the characterization of protests as riots, arguing that state law enforcement is sufficient and that the situation in Chicago is not comparable to wartime scenarios like the War of 1812.
A divided three-judge panel of the 9th Circuit recently upheld the president's right to deploy the National Guard, though the full 9th Circuit is considering whether to reconsider this decision.
The Supreme Court's ruling in this case could have broad implications for future federal deployments of the National Guard in response to protests or civil unrest across the United States.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump is urging the U.S. Supreme Court to allow the deployment of the National Guard to Chicago to address protests against ICE operations, citing a recent 9th Circuit ruling that supports presidential deference in similar deployments in Portland and Los Angeles. The administration argues that the protests constitute 'violent resistance' and that the president has exclusive authority to determine such emergencies, relying on the 1827 precedent of Martin v. Mott. However, Illinois officials and Judge April Perry dispute this, asserting that local law enforcement is sufficient and that the protests do not equate to wartime threats. The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision within days, with implications extending to other cities where the administration may seek Guard deployment.
title: Trump touts Oregon National Guard ruling as Supreme Court weighs deployment to Chicago
